q2.description:
A configuration for a Turing machine looks like this: (q, aaba)

This means that the TM is on state q, the tape contains aaba and the read/write head position is on the underlined 'a'. Recall that we assume at the start of processing input for any TM, the read/write head position is on the leftmost non-blank character.

Don't forget that the tape is infinite in both directions. So to the left of the leftmost 'a' in this configuration is an infinite number of blank squares, and to the right of the rightmost a is also an infinite number of blank squares.
q2.question: How many cells exists in a TM tape?
choices: The same as the length of the input string
The same as the length of the input string + some empry cells

q6.description:
A computation is a sequence of configurations of some length $n \ge 0$.
Example:
Recall the TM example that erases all a's from the tape.
q6.question: What is the meanin of this configuration $(q_0, \underline{a}aaa)$?
answer: The underlined $a$ represents the current read/write head location
choices: The underlined $a$ represents the current read/write head location

q7.description:
A computation is a sequence of configurations of some length $n \ge 0$.
Example:
Recall the TM example that erases all a's from the tape.
q7.question: Based on the current configuration $(q_0, \underline{a}aaa)$, what is the next configuration?

q8.description:
A computation is a sequence of configurations of some length $n \ge 0$.
Example:
Recall the TM example that erases all a's from the tape.
q8.question: Based on the current configuration $(q_0, \underline{a}aaa)\vdash_M(q_0, \underline{\#}aaa)$, what is the next configuration?

q9.description:
A computation is a sequence of configurations of some length $n \ge 0$.
Example:
Recall the TM example that erases all a's from the tape.
q9.question:
Based on the current configuration $(q_0, \underline{a}aaa)\vdash_M(q_0, \underline{\#}aaa)$
$\quad \quad \vdash_M(q_0, \#\underline{\#}aa)$, what is the next configuration?

q10.description:
A computation is a sequence of configurations of some length $n \ge 0$.
Example:
Recall the TM example that erases all a's from the tape.
q10.question:
Based on the current configuration $(q_0, \underline{a}aaa)\vdash_M(q_0, \underline{\#}aaa)$
$\quad \quad \vdash_M(q_0, \#\underline{\#}aa)$
$\quad \quad \vdash_M(q_0, \#\#\underline{\#}a)$, what is the next configuration?

q11.description:
A computation is a sequence of configurations of some length $n \ge 0$.
Example:
Recall the TM example that erases all a's from the tape.
q11.question:
Based on the current configuration $(q_0, \underline{a}aaa)\vdash_M(q_0, \underline{\#}aaa)$
$\quad \quad \vdash_M(q_0, \#\underline{\#}aa)$
$\quad \quad \vdash_M(q_0, \#\#\underline{\#}a)$
$\quad \quad \vdash_M(q_0, \#\#\#\underline{\#})$, what is the next configuration?

q15.description:
What is a "hanging" configuration? The machine hangs when it goes into an infinite loop. Anytime you provide the mechanism to create loops that only end on a condition, you have also created the conditions that might allow an infinite loop to happen.
Consider this machine on strings of a's and b's that scans right until it sees a 'b'.
q15.question: What will happen if the tape has no $b$?
q15.answer: The machine will go to infinite loop
choices: The machine will go to infinite loop
The machine will halt and reject the string
The machine will halt and accept the string

q16.description:
What is a "hanging" configuration? The machine hangs when it goes into an infinite loop. Anytime you provide the mechanism to create loops that only end on a condition, you have also created the conditions that might allow an infinite loop to happen.
Consider this machine on strings of a's and b's that scans right until it sees a 'b'. If it never sees a 'b', then it will never halt. This means that it goes into an infinite loop (or hangs) anytime the input string does not contain a 'b'.
q16.question: Since the machine entered an infinity loop, it is in hanging configuration

q17.description:
Turing Acceptors and Turing Transducers

Turing machines accpets and recjects string based on the language they represent.
q17.question: What are other models we know that can accept/reject strings?

q18.description:
Turing Transducers

Turing machines alos can compute functions from strings to strings. This means that, the machine will start with a string in the tape and after it finishs the execution, the tape will contain the output string
q18.question: What are other models we know that can compute functions?
q18.answer: None of them can compute functions
choices: None of them can compute functions
